hints.content:
##Forming the number:

We have a two-digit number. The digit at **units** place is $\maroonD{u}$ and let the digit at **tens** place be $\goldD{t}$.

Hence, our initial number is $10\goldD{t}+\maroonD{u}$.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
A number is formed when the digits of the number are multiplied with its corresponding place value.

For e.g. 

$\begin{align}
24&=(2\times10)+(4\times1)\\
67&=(6\times10)+(7\times1)
\end{align}$

Hence, it won't be fair to assume a  two-digit number as $\goldD{t}\maroonD{u}$, as it would mean the product of $\goldD{t}$ and $\maroonD{u}$. 

We can assume a two-digit number as $10\goldD{t}+\maroonD{u}$.

hints.content:
##Forming 1st equation:

When the two-digit number and its **reverse** are added to each other we get $143$.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

This means,

$(10\goldD{t}+\maroonD{u})+(10\maroonD{u}+\goldD{t})=143$

Bingo! We have our first equation.

options.explanation:
When the digits of a two-digit number interchange their places we say that the number has been reversed.

For e.g. reverse of $24$ is $42$.

hints.content:
##Forming 2nd equation:

For the initial number, we get the digit at **tens** place when $7$ is subtracted from the square of the **units** digit.

This means,

$\goldD{t}=\maroonD{u}^2-7$

Yippee! We have our $2^{\text{nd}}$ equation as well.

##Eliminating t:

Now, our two equations are:

$\begin{cases}
(10\goldD{t}+\maroonD{u})+(10\maroonD{u}+\goldD{t})=143\\\\
\goldD{t}=\maroonD{u}^2-7
\end{cases}$

From the $1^{\text{st}}$ equation,

$\begin{align}
11\goldD{t}+11\maroonD{u}&=143\\\\
t+u&=13\\\\
t&=13-u
\end{align}$

Substituting this value in $2^{\text{nd}}$ equation,

$\begin{align}
\goldD{t}&=\maroonD{u}^2-7\\\\
\goldD{(13-u)}&=\maroonD{u}^2-7
\end{align}$

This is all we need!

question.content:
When a two-digit number and its reverse are added to each other we get $143$.

For the initial number, the digit at tens place is obtained when $7$ is subtracted from the square of the units digit.

Let the digit at units place of the initial number be $u$.

**Write an equation in $u$.**  
*Note: You don’t need to input the equation in quadratic form.*

[[☃ expression 1]]
